TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit Whitening extends Microsoft.ML.Runtime.Data.TrainedWrapperEstimatorBase
Public NotInheritable Class Whitening Inherits TrainedWrapperEstimatorBase

Docs.summary: Implements PCA (Principal Component Analysis) and ZCA (Zero phase Component Analysis) whitening. The whitening process consists of 2 steps: 1. Decorrelation of the input data. Input data is assumed to have zero mean. 2. Rescale decorrelated features to have unit variance. That is, PCA whitening is essentially just a PCA + rescale. ZCA whitening tries to make resulting data to look more like input data by rotating it back to the original input space. More information: http://ufldl.stanford.edu/wiki/index.php/Whitening

MemberSignature.Value: public Whitening (Microsoft.ML.Runtime.IHostEnvironment env, ValueTuple<string,string>[] columns, Microsoft.ML.Runtime.Data.WhiteningKind kind = Microsoft.ML.Runtime.Data.WhiteningKind.Zca, float eps = 1E-05, int maxRows = 100000, bool saveInverse = false, int pcaNum = 0);

Docs.summary: Implements PCA (Principal Component Analysis) and ZCA (Zero phase Component Analysis) whitening. The whitening process consists of 2 steps: 1. Decorrelation of the input data. Input data is assumed to have zero mean. 2. Rescale decorrelated features to have unit variance. That is, PCA whitening is essentially just a PCA + rescale. ZCA whitening tries to make resulting data to look more like input data by rotating it back to the original input space. More information: http://ufldl.stanford.edu/wiki/index.php/Whitening

The column containing output tokens. Null means is replaced.
Docs.summary: Implements PCA (Principal Component Analysis) and ZCA (Zero phase Component Analysis) whitening. The whitening process consists of 2 steps: 1. Decorrelation of the input data. Input data is assumed to have zero mean. 2. Rescale decorrelated features to have unit variance. That is, PCA whitening is essentially just a PCA + rescale. ZCA whitening tries to make resulting data to look more like input data by rotating it back to the original input space. More information: http://ufldl.stanford.edu/wiki/index.php/Whitening
